item.title: YAPYAP Surpasses 500,000 Copies Sold
item.content:encoded:
YAPYAP sold half 1 million games in its first week on the market.

YAPYAP, a co-op horror game where players use microphones to cast magic spells and wreak havoc in enemy wizards’ towers, was released on Steam in early February 2026. Within a week of its release, the game had sold 500,000 copies. This is despite the game still smoothing out some rough edges.

Maison Bap Reacts to YAPYAP’s Major Milestone

Maison Bap, the game’s publisher and developer, shared a message of gratitude upon reaching the milestone. They noted that over the coming weeks, they will continue to fix bugs and polish the game. They will then focus on additional content once all edges are smoothed.

“We also know many of you are eager to hear about future updates, but before jumping into new features and content, we want to make sure the game is fully stable and smooth for everyone. Once that’s locked in, we’ll start planning the fun stuff,” the team said in a message that was shared on Steam on February 9.

The game is still on a small introductory discount. It is currently available on Steam for $7.99.

For more YAPYAP on Insider Gaming, check out our official walkthrough. Also, learn everything you need to know about all of the monsters you will encounter in the game.

Have you picked up YAPYAP? What do you think of the Indie game so far? Sound off in our official Discord server. Also, don’t forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.

item.title: Sega Reports Over $200M Rovio Impairment in Q3 Earnings
item.content:encoded:
Sega says Sonic Rumble underperformed and that, overall, the value of the Angry Birds developer Rovio was written down, resulting in an impairment loss of more than $200 million.

Sega Sammy Holdings Inc., Sega’s parent company, recently reported its Q3 earnings for fiscal year 2026. Noted in the earnings that, as it pertained to Rovio’s business, there was a recognized impairment loss of approximately 31.3 billion yen. As of this writing, that amounts to about $205 million.

Sega completed its acquisition of Rovio in August 2023.

Factors Surrounding Rovio’s Underperforming Quarter

In the Q3 presentation, Sega attributes Rovio’s performance falling short of initial expectations to “rapid changes in the market environment and other factors.” One of those factors was the collaborative mobile title Sonic Rumble, which struggled to meet key performance indicators.

Moving forward, Sega plans to reverse this momentum by focusing specifically on Angry Birds and Sega IPs, including Sonic, for future games. They also see the release of the third Angry Birds movie, set for December, as another factor driving hopeful increased traction for the brand.

The Future of Sonic

Sonic Rumble, which is also available for free on Steam, may have underperformed, but the blue blur always bounces back. It’s Sonic’s 35th anniversary this year. So far, no official game releases have been scheduled in celebration, but the Sonic Team has put out a new audio drama in the Sonic universe. Learn more about that here.

Elsewhere in the filings, Sega announced plans to make mainstay IPs a focus not just in mobile releases but also in traditional console releases. Read more about that here.

Do you still play Angry Birds? Did you play Sonic Rumble? What did you think of the game? Sound off in our official Discord server. Also, don’t forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.

item.title: The Six Games Ubisoft Has Canceled Amid Restructuring
item.content:encoded:
When Ubisoft announced that the Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time Remake was canceled, it was also revealed that five other games were ending. Insider Gaming has learned the six games that have been cancelled at Ubisoft.

First reported on Insider Gaming Weekly, Insider Gaming understands that the following six games were canceled:

  • Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time Remake – Canceled after being first announced in 2020.
  • Project Ether – In development since 2019, which was canceled, but has morphed, in a way, into a newer project. Believed to have been in development at Ubisoft Halifax.
  • Project Pathfinder – Known previously as Project U
  • Project Crest – A World War 2 extraction shooter
  • Assassin’s Creed Rebellion – Stopping support
  • Assassin’s Creed Singularity – A new mobile Assassin’s Creed Game

Along with the game cancellations that were previously announced—confirmed above—there was also a multiplayer Assassin’s Creed that had reportedly been shuttered. That game, however, isn’t a part of this group.

One game that is still coming is the Assassin’s Creed: Blag Flag Remake. The latest rumors suggest that a reveal will take place in April after being delayed out of the current fiscal year.

If you want to go directly to the moment in the show below, it takes place around the 54:07 mark.

What do you think of the six cancelled games at Ubisoft? Leave your thoughts down in the comments and join the discussion in the official Insider Gaming Discord.

And for even more Insider Gaming delivered directly to your inbox, sign up for our weekly newsletter.

Mike has been covering the gaming industry since 2012, and has reported on some of the largest events in the industry while also working as an investigative reporter. Outside of…
